comments.commentBody: When something like this happens, it's not just one mistake along the way.  Multiple errors at multiple levels by multiple people are involved, much as you might see with a major aircraft accident.  I was really surprised when I read that one evening at midnight the child was throwing up and had the unusual leg pain, but the article seemed to indicate it wasn't until the following evening that the pediatrician saw the patient.  This patient seems to have gone long periods of time between being seen by a professional, and when he was, the professional missed or overlooked critical signs or results.  Parents should have demanded all lab results and researched the meaning of those results themselves.  Heck, when my pet goes to the vet office and gets labwork, I ask for a copy of the results and question anything out of the normal range.  This poor kid seems like he was treated on the parents' and doctors' schedule (they waited until the next morning in two cases, and waited on their pediatrician in two more).  I would point to the long length of time it took to treat him as a major contributing cause.  Very sad story, sounds like he was a pretty good kid.

Pathogenic bacteria, including the super-virulent ones which are methicillin resistant, are all around us. We harbor them on our bodies with no awareness of this fact, and generally with no evident damage. We don't know why they occasionally cause sickness and sometimes death in specific people, at specific times.

However, any physical trauma is a great opportunity for them to thrive at our expense. As another commenter has noted, it seems that the boy's injury was not properly cleaned and treated with topical antibiotics *immediately* after it occurred. I wish more commenters had picked up on this critical detail.

What a profound and moving le4sson this story carries.  I hope every medical center and professional in the country reads it with care.  I remain unable to understabnd, though, what it was about contact with a floor in a basketball game could do to cause it.  Do gym floors need to be treated with antiseptic, and would it do any good?
Medicare and Medicaid are single payer, and they pay for this

As long as we have a health care system that is not a single payer government system, there will be individuals and businesses trying to game the system to make money, sometimes enormous amounts, as this article indicates.  Plug one loophole and another will be found; it's inevitable.  There is only one way to put a end to this, but I doubt it will happen in the lifetime of anyone now living.

I disagree that Rory's symptoms were consistent with viral gastroenteritis; the severe leg pain and skin mottling are not.  Also, if his abnormal vital signs were caused by dehydration they should have normalized after IV hydration.  This is a good warning to parents not to put much trust in the doctors and not to hesitate to take a child to another ER, or to take the child to the ER even if the pediatrician says it's unnecessary.  Of course this would put even more strain on our dysfunctional health care system!  My heart does go out to the doctors who made this sad mistake, but we need to be honest with ourselves.  We're giving inadequate care because of time pressures and overscheduling and concerns about money.  Healthy 12 year olds with this constellation of signs & symptoms are no longer healthy and they deserve time and attention and quality care.  This is a problem we need to address as a society rather than a problem with the individual doctors.  But doctors need to get honest with themselves and stop pretending that this typical care is adequate care.  It is not.

Furthermore, while those savings are sitting in a CD, bank account, or money market fund, the money is available for loans for small businesses, home improvement, or mortgages. Savings is better for the economy than more waste in so-called safety net programs.

Its not even Keynsian. What Keynes preached was a government that spent less than it takes in during good times so that it had cold hard cash to spend during bad times. What Obama did has nothing to do with that at all, because the US government almost always operates in a state of deficit. Obama just printed cash from nothing and borrowed some more from China. Not a healthy way to run the economy.

You're right. I work in a small ED that sends patients home all the time with fever and blood cultures still pending. But blood cultures are never drawn exclusively of other labs. And you can be darn sure that a physician has reviewed the results of those other labs -- incluing the complete blood count that Rorydid undergo, and which showed an alarming white count -- before they are discharged. I'm not blaming the ED docs, either, without complete information. But I'm baffled as to why, when his alarming lab results were available only two hours later, Rory was already at home.

Cost? The failure of my doctor to recognize sepsis in a timely way nearly killed me, caused me to spend 8 days in the ICU, 35 days in the hospital, 3 months bedridden with 24-hour care, three follow-up surgeries---and a $2.2 million medical bill.

It would have been much cheaper and far more humane to have diagnosed the problem in a timely way.

The drunk guy at the end of the bar doesn't get to decide whether or not he's fit to drive home.

If JJJ is so sick that he hasn't been able to report to in over a month, then other people need to step in and decide what the next step is.

JJJ can have all the privacy in the world if he steps down from congress. Until then, deal with the scrutiny.

ANetliner - As a public servant, Mr. Jackson's "privacy and space" does not include: absent for 2 weeks hoping no one will notice; make a general statement about "exhaustion" when someone does notice; and changing to "mood disorder" when his possible location is leaked as a facility that mostly treats alcoholism.

Mr. Jackson is a public servant who has been unable to serve for over a month. He (or his office) has a duty to inform the people he serves of his true condition. Meeting your obligation to inform as a public servant is not depriving Mr. Jackson of any "privacy and space", he has that already. They can release his condition without the location and name of his doctor.

As a physician, I find the barbs being aimed at Congressman Jackson to be quite cruel. If he has a mood disorder, then he appropriately needs to take a brief medical leave of absence to get treatment and recover. The stigma attached to psychiatric disorders is appalling.  What about Senator Gabrielle Gifford? She was on an extended medical leave and was not condemned for being unfit to serve and her constituents did not quickly ask that she resign. Her injuries proved too extensive for continued service, but this decision was made 5-6 months after she sustained her injury. She was given the opportunity to seek treatment and attempt to recover. Why is it that those with treatable mental health issues are treated so differently than those with other types of medical crises?

Congressman Jackson deserves privacy and space to work through his psychological and medical problems.

If Congressman Jackson believes that he is unable to serve his constituents, he should resign so that another candidate can be placed on the ballot. If the Congressman feels that he is still able to serve, he should make his case to the voters before November. I would expect that his re-election campaign would address his physical and ppsychological fitness to perform his public duties.

At the moment, though, Congressman Jackson needs the privacy to seek medical treatment and to heal. I hope that his privacy is respected-- at least until the start of the fall campaign, assuming that he remains in the race.

I also cried reading this article. I cannot imagine how I would go on if something like this happened to my little boy.

I am so happy for you that everything worked out for your son.

As a physician I know how easy it can be to "Monday Morning Quarterback". This ER doc probably treated 10 people for a GI virus and dehydration that day and Rory's presentation looked enough like the others to fool him. And he probably took care of 60 patients on his shift. But what bothers me is that simple physical exam and vital sign abnormalities seemed to be ignored. Dehydration can cause a fast heart rate (tachycardia) but usually doesn't make you breathe too fast, as Rory was described to be doing. And a history of a cut, leg pain, fever, and blotchy skin rash. Infection should be high on the possibility list and the lab test, a CBC (complete blood count) would be a critical piece of information to me before I ventured to make my final diagnosis. It just seems so obvious in retrospect, but again, the facts don't always line up so neatly in the heat of battle... or the din of a hectic ER.
I am so sorry for your loss.  Words are not enough. . .

My god, you're right. She is a pediatrician. I'm ashamed. I stand by my general rant, but I would have expected more sensitivity and attention to detail from a pediatrician. She must be hating herself.

Strep pyogenes is a really bad bug...one of the few that regularly kills healthy kids. But, it's easy to kill with antibiotics, and he would have been saved if he had been treated the first day.

she should have recognized his clinical syndrome with or without the labs, but no one is dumb enough to ignore 53 bands. it must have gotten lost in the shuffle of the night. That doesn't amke the system any less culpable.

It seems almost surreal in a sense that Mitt Romney would have made a speech to the NAACP at this point in the campaign. The strategically wise choice would be to wait until the last minute, so as to minimize the damage.

Unless Mitt Romney's staff and advisers are mentally ill, they could have at least prepared him to be somewhat more conciliatory towards this audience. While many in the broader American media may believe that Romney can beat Obama without capturing a substantial number of black votes, that just does not fit with what history has demonstrated.

The fact that Rupert Murdoch and Rush Limbaugh seem ready to criticize Romney freely seem to indicate that many have already conceded the Presidency to Obama, regardless of what the Republican Party says. Romney may appear to be viable currently, but it is likely that as the election approaches, his public popularity will wither-even with the war chest that has been accumulated by his campaign.

It appears that, more than an actual effort to beat Obama, the money flowing into the Romney campaign is meant to disempower any efforts by Barack Obama to move towards a more "Progressive" agenda. If he cannot be beaten, at least he can be nullified. That really does appear to be tacit message that the Republicans are sending.

Just a thought!

Romney's follow-up remark was especially telling: "If they want more stuff from government, tell them to go vote for the other guy — more free stuff."

CELINE and DEEPBLUESEA are debuting today?! Both have been around for long enough.

Left side was a breeze, but the right side was trickier, as it took Dad a while to remember CHARYBDIS and I ignorantly put IDYLLSAND, not realizing that contradicted ASIGN, which of course made the musical AIDS. (Which apparently took place in Egypt.)

Speaking of which, I find it really hypocritical that puzzles can acknowledge E. COLI, but not Acquired ImmunoDefiency Syndrome. The first one is rather disgusting and shouldn't need any more discussion at the breakfast table besides "Wash your hands with soap." The second one is a virus millions are affected with, with no cure or vaccine despite decades of research, and all it takes is exchange of body fluids, which could easily happen "out of the gutter."

I think MDs are focusing on the bands of 50% because it is a less subjective finding - and "hard" data that suggests the patient should have been admitted. Obviously the physical exam would have been critical but one wants to give the MDs involved the benefit of the doubt......

Unfortunately, my limited experience with invasive Group A Strep, as a non-ID/non-surgical doc, is that many MDs don't appreciate what to do with the clinical picture and physical findings. So many don't know for example the appropriate combo of antibiotics. Or there was the surgical resident I paged out of bed at 1 AM who told me the crepitations we were palpating on a patient's foot was "just cellulitis" - and the patient was in the OR 30 minutes after the staff Plastic surgeon saw her in the morning.

Yes! It's called history taking_talking to the child and the mother. Put aside your medical hat-a young kid with horrific leg pain and no fracture! Febrile,tachycardia,dehydration-so much that even IV fluids administered-it's all a bit surreal for me as an academic physician but I suppose the best I can say is that we may not have the whole story.

Couldn't agree more with you- history,physical exam (the red flag skin mottling not tested for?)-a presumptive diagnosis it seems should have been made.

The purpose of lab tests here should have been to support a presumptive clinical diagnosis. Once upon a time, nurses were stellar in eliciting the little nuggets of information to differentiate the trivial from the serious and keep the MDs in line. Unfortunately,it seems this input which might have put the MD on alert and press the panic button was absent.

Interesting how the focus of the comments (and the article) is on the vital signs and lab values. Very little focus by most of the MD commentators about the symptoms and absolutely no mention of the physical exam of the child in the ED regarding the leg. One reason I became a surgeon, and then a vascular surgeon, is the importance in my field of symptoms and the physical exam. While the lab values are obviously important in the assessment, two things strike me about this tragic case:

1) one phone call from the primary MD to the ER might have saved his life. When I send a patient to any ER, especially someone that calls me with symptoms and that I cannot pre-evaluate beforehand, I always call ahead and say "I am sending Mr. XXX to your ER. He is en route. I am worried about aortic rupture/infection/bleeding/thrombosis, etc. Please evaluate him and have the ER doc call me on my cell phone." The most important surgical instrument in 2012 remains the cellular phone.

2) This story repeatedly states how much Rory's leg hurt. In the absence of a fracture and with a break in the skin, this is classic for a necrotizing soft tissue infection. It is not clear that anyone looked closely at his leg. Pain out of proportion to physical findings is also a sign of this. To often nowadays, we focus on the labs, the vitals, the "sepsis checklist" and we are not examining the patients with a focus on the affected areas. I doubt the exam was normal of his leg.
